title: lithlamp - compact Interchangeable lithopane lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have designed a lamp base to hold lithopanes like -http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74322
I wanted it to be small and interchangeable so it could be used as a light or as a display for your pictures,I will use mine as a bedside lamp as it gives of a nice low light.
The lamp is a 6W Pure White Square 5730 SMD Led Panel Light Ceiling Light Lamp 700LM AC85-265V I purchased from ebay. update 15.10.14 there are more size options on the lithopane customiser now, the light fits panes 104mm wide so you need to use the square setting for shape, and large for size.

This is an idea I have been playing with for a while now, I have printed a few lithopanes for myself and friends and wanted a way to display them.
I started by looking for a light source that was close to the lithopane size and not to bright, on ebay I found 6W Pure White Square 5730 SMD Led Panel Light Ceiling Light Lamp 700LM AC85-265V and set about modifying them to a lamp.
I removed the orignal front and designed a new one with Tinkercad,I changed the front as the hole in the center of the orignal front was too small and would not illuminate all of the picture.
I then made the edge peice to hold the lithopane and attached it with super glue to the front.The cutout on the front goes to the top to help pull the lithopanes out (most of mine dont have the ring printed).
I did not print the screw holes in the front plate as they are very small,when printed I used the back to mark the hole positions and then pilot drilled with a 1mm drill taking care not to go all the way through,I think the screws are number 4 x 1/2 " as they measure 2.8mm dia and 12.5mm long.
I replaced the orignal cable grip on the rear of the lamp with the stand which has the grip built into it.
The stand can be fitted with the orignal screws.
I fitted the front so the cable grip was at 9 o clock when looking from the back.
I fitted a lead to the lamp that had an inline switch just for ease of use when using as a bedside lamp.
Before fitting test the lamp with your lithopanes for brightness,I print mine at 0.2 layer and 12 to 14 layes so mine come out around 3mm thick but some people might make theres thicker.(the slot at the front will take 4mm)
If you find it a bit too bright as I did print and fit defuser in the back.
My parts were printed In white ABS on a reprappro mono mendel with a 0.5mm nozzle, print 1 off each part as bellow. should be fine in PLA but not tested.
Front -printed at 0.3 layer 50% fill with 4 solid bottom layes as I dont want infill on the lens area of the print
Edge- printed at 0.2 layer 70% fill to get a good clean print
defuser - printed at 0.3 layer at 100% fill as again dont want any infill patten to shine through the lithopane.
Stand - printed at 0.2 layer 50% fill
You will also need the 4 screws to fit the new front and some flex and a plug.
This project involves a very small amount of electrics and the modification of a piece of lighting.
I have run mine for several hours with no issues of heat in the front of the lamp, the rear aluminium part gets warm as its there as a heat sink. use at your own discretion.
please feel free to make, copy, modify as you like but please dont sell it on.
please feel free to ask any questions.
hope you like it :)

description.text:
The Lyman Filament Extruder V6 was designed and built originally for a Church Group through Pastor Glenn Grimsley.  As Glenn has had a bad accident and no longer communicates with me I have changed the Creative Commons Attributions to Share Alike.
This simple extruder worked so well I have made three, one for black, one white and one for other colored filaments.

V6 Extruder is the simplest one I have designed and is easy to make and is inexpensive. Also, I am extruding the best ABS filaments with it. As the design progressed a number of items have been updated, so I am including most of the 69 STL files created, though less than 20 are used. Thus you should go through them a pick the ones that you are capable of printing. The attached Construction Manual should give you enough information to create one. In it is the BOM and wiring diagrams. The Spool Winder is not included here but will be available in a new thing. I have three (3) V6 extruders, one for white, one for black and the third for other color filaments. Two items I do not use, one is the fan and the other is the variable speed control. I found that in my shop configuration that all I needed was the temperature adjustment and the nozzle size to control the diameter of the filament.

The heat band I used is 110V, 1" ID. Mine had to be stretch a little to fit the 1" black iron coupler.

comments.text:
I have been following your project and was also investigating the subject with my similar construction extruder (auger drill, one heater on die with Proportional–Integral–Derivative controllers) . My main objective being PLA extrusion.
Though I have managed to make a spool of material using which I have made a few prints (for example http://www.thingiverse.com/make:202028 and http://www.thingiverse.com/make:190008 ) I have learned that PLA due to different viscosity and cooling characteristics will not extrude well with extruder of such simplified construction. First of all it certainly needs better (better mixed and more homogenous) melt than a simple auger drill and external heater can provide, and needs specific cooling. Cooling apparently has to be gradual in accordance to a certain "cooling curve" (ABS is more tolerant to the above things but unfortunately I can't stand the smell of ABS :). Too fast cooling shall produce bubbles and consequently bad shape of the extrudate, while too slow cooling makes it very hard to control the thickness within decent tolerance due to too long natural cooling time of the PLA. Therefore I am now in process of acquiring a good bi-metalic pair of extrusion screw/barrel (screw should be from a metal which provides slippage against pellets while barrel vice-versa should have higher friction to the resin). Also as 70% of heating in the case of the changing diameter screw should come from inter-pellet friction rather than from external heating, the motor and gear mechanism should be much more powerful. Then ... the cooling part - probably the easiest would be a dual temperature water bath cooler.

The ABS pellets I use are very high temp.  The temp in my V1 printer requires a temp of 275° C and my V2 printer temp is 280° C to print with my extruded filament which is extruded at 210° C.

comments.text: How did you make the nozzle? I found Fastenal Part No. (SKU): 440015-131280 but there is no hole in it. Which one did you find with a hole in it? What size hole? How big would you need to extrude 1.75mm fillament?
comments.author: ccrom1

comments.text: You will need to drill a hole in the brass plug.  For 1.75mm start with a #54 drill bit and test it, if too thin ream the hole with the next size larger bit #53 and so on.  I counter sink the inside (intake) to a 1/2" diameter and dress the outside (exhaust) by hand so there are no burrs on at the hole edge.  Then I clean it good with a pipe cleaner.

Prusa I3

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

10%

Snowman designed from Autodesk 123D From the primitives selection I inserted 3 spheres. Then scaled them from small, medium and large and stacked. From the primitives selection again, I selected the torus and scaled it down to fit around the neck. Then added two additional torus's and rotated them to finish the scarf ends. The hat was created by extruding a circle sketch of two different diameters and then placed on top. The eyes and buttons are all made from primitive spheres. The nose is a cone selected from primitives and scaled down to fit proportionally.

This is a simple dining table consisting out of five pieces of two kinds. Designed to be made out of 30 mm thick plywood on a big router (ShopBot  or whatever else with working surface at least 1200*1200 mm). Laminated plywood would work just fine, otherwise finishing is needed.
Cut the countour with 6 mm bit. Assemble the legs inserting one into another, put the desktop on the top. No glue, no scews.

Inspired by several of the shelving systems here on Thingiverse, this is a customizable system for creating hexagonal shelves. (I'd list the sources but it looks like the search function for remixes is not working???)
The big difference here is that it is done as a script in OpenSCAD so you can very easily adapt it to different thicknesses of material, screws, etc.
By default it is set to work with 1/4" plywood, and #8 self-tapping screws to secure it.
It is possible to generate the brackets either "open" or "closed" - the latter fills in one side of the bracket and is probably stronger.
One (recommended) change is to make the thickness of the bracket an exact multiple of your layer width. For example, if you make it 2.4 mm and print it with 3 shells, you will get a piece that consists entirely of shells, which will look good and be strong.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: Pretty easy to print.
Assembly is pretty straightforward, the pieces should friction fit. You can then lock the pieces in place by using self-tapping #8 screws, about 1/2" or less in length.

The whole thing is a single OpenSCAD script. (I may update it to work as a customizer.)
The idea is that you can change the thickness of the shelf material in one place, and generate all the various bits.

description.text: An arm which attatchs the the side of the Z Makerslides. Holds a standard ABEC bearing (Out of skateboard Etc) 22mm OD, 8mm ID, 7mm H. Have to replace the 8mm threaded rod and increase the length to maintain 150mm Z travel. I cut the rods to match the height of the makerslides. description.text:
My goal for this project was to make something modern that compliments the pen. I have not tried printing it yet, I have fit checked it in the model and it fits fine. There should be a slight spring action on the part so that the pen locks into the dock. This is a pen dock I designed for this kickstarter pen:
http://thetinmill.com/products/tipe-titanium-helical-bolt-action-pen This dock should work for most pens relatively well. I suggest bonding it in the post-printing instructions.

Bond it to the wall or desk You can bond it to the wall or your desk using this 3M tape:
http://solutions.3m.com/wps/portal/3M/en_US/Adhesives/Tapes/Products/~/3M-Double-Coated-Cloth-Tape-543?N=8302947+3293082833&rt=rud Cut a 1.5" square piece of tape and securely fasten to bottom of pen dock

description.text:
This is a fun little interlocking puzzle that will give you a pyramid when it's all finished!
I actually designed the puzzle into little cubes in order to make a linear and simplistic, yet a complicated solution for it. What better cubed world to do it in than minecraft? I then copied what I did on my minecraft world to tinkercad and made a printable version of the pyramid.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple White

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100, Dealing with very small, solid pieces

Notes:
  • These little parts don't like to stick to the bed for me, so I'd recommend a raft to keep everything down on the bed and easy to take off of it.
  • It the piece doesn't fit, it's probably on the wrong way!
  • The pyramid itself is only 35mm across, so it only takes about an hour of print time.
Every piece turned out very well in this amazing orange PLA!
I completely designed the pyramid in minecraft because it was easier for me to do so, plus it's fun at the same time!

This mash-up was made as a b-day gift for my freind who really loves "The Tao of Pooh" http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Tao_of_Pooh
It was a big hit.
UPDATE - I noticed the bottom is not flat, so I have uploaded a new STL with a flat bottom, this makes adding a message to the underside easier. I like the idea of adding a message to the base, I used this quote from the book "A clever mind is not a heart." and this is on the file called "poohdda+heart-mind saying.stl"
adding text was not too bad using blender to extrude the text and tinkercad.com to make the text a hole and put it on the base. also to help educate your friends and family, best I have found under 2 minute slightly amusing, simple & straight forward explanation of home 3D printing, (made by and for schools):
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YpHv19jdloI

the picts are of this printed on ultimaker, 0.4mm nozzel, in PLA, 0.2mm layer hieght, and 0.8mm walls. I got some gaps especially on pooh's head..which seems to be the most troubling spot, SO I have also unploaded my pooh-crown-4-testing.stl file. make sure you have your settings so this part comes out good before you print the whole thing.
next time i will go with 0.1mm layer height and 1.2mm walls, also see pic.

title: Velleman Vertex K8400 auto bed leveling add-on

description.text:
With this add-on you can use Marlin's auto bed leveling feature on your Velleman Vertex K8400 3D printer. In order to use this add-on you need to make several changes to your printer:
  • Print the STL's for the servo holder and the micro switch arm.
  • Solder a 2x9 PCB connector with a wire connected to the SS pin of the LCD.
    This pin isn't in use by any components so we can hijack it for our purpose without soldering on the mainboard.
  • Mount the servo in the holder, solder some wires to the servo and the microswitch.
  • Mount the microswitch on the arm.
  • Use some M3 screws to mount the component on the place where you should mount the 2nd head.
  • Provide a seperate 5V power supply (like a 7805) to power the servo. I used 2 extra PCB traces to connect the servo signal and microswitch signal as well.
  • Connect the wires and test if the servo responds
  • Flash the firmware.
  • Modify the PROBE OFFSETS and SERVO ANGLES in Configuration.h, if necessary.
  • Test your configuration by running the following Gcode:
    G28 (home)
    G29 (level bed)
    • The micro switch arm STL can you find here:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:902402 Feel free to modify this add-on and to share your prints/work! WARNING: I am not responsible for any damage to your 3D printer!

Printer:

Velleman Vertex K8400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: Cooling is necessary!

description.text:
MakerBot Robot Competition
This is Frank, he is a MakerBot Robot V1.7_13. Frank is a robot designed to bridge the language gap between Humans and any possible Extraterrestrial life that tries to communicate with us.
Since Frank toddled off the production line late 2011, he has been pondering a question while waiting to fulfill his purpose. The question he has been pondering is whether or not he should ponder the meaning of life or whether he should ponder how to level up his Caterpie in Pokemon. This question shall plague him for a while yet as Frank was build to Ponder and discover.

description.text:
The Mockingjay emblem from the Hunger Games movies. Since I couldn't find any truly volumetric, non plain model, I've decided to try and model it myself. I've modeled it on ZBrush and tidy up a bit on blender. This is my first attempt at modeling something with ZBrush so it is not very high quality, although it is good enough to get great results from a printer.
The print in the pictures has been printed using ColorFabb's copperfill, polished with dremel and smeared with black shoe polish.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes: The model is not perfectly manifold... sorry about that. Slic3r has trouble with it, so I had to use cura instead. Cura handled it with no problem whatsoever. Edit: I've uploaded a new model fixed with netfabb. It should work now with any slicer software.

7 days, 3 times per day Rotary pill dispenser.

2x 608z bearings used in this build Print 1 base, 1 lid and 3 feet, then scale a foot by 2x in all axis and print that to use as a handle. This build needs 2x 608Z bearings, so that the lid and base rotate freely, it is a slight push fit with both the shaft into the bearing and the bearings into the base, but once all together is nice and smooth running and won't open if dropped or knocked, i left a blank so that the aperture can be placed over this and again if knocked or dropped the pills wont spill out. I then used a little Acetone-ABS mix as glue to stick the feet and handle onto the base and lid. I printed mine on a Up!Plus at 0.25mm layers and Normal speed using CD-Writer Red and Blue ABS, this unfortunately resulted in the text not being printed very well at all, please feel free to improve on this design. Ive included my STL and Sketchup drawings.

description.text: airplane by me

Kites and Darts are a type of non-periodic tiling invented by Roger Penrose. The tiles cover the plane in an infinite variety of beautiful, non-repeating patterns. The Golden Ratio (1/2)*(1+sqrt(5)) features prominently in the tiles, in their construction and in their patterns. In the limit, the ratio of kites to darts is the golden ratio. So if you print 1000 darts you should print 1618 kites. There are seven ways the tiles can be arranged around a vertex. These seven patterns were given names by John Conway and appear in the stl files: sun, star, ace, deuce, jack, queen, king. The circular markings show how the edges of the tiles line up. The circular patterns themselves are interesting, and if you want you can print and use only the markings. See these links for more information:
http://intendo.net/penrose/info.html
http://mathworld.wolfram.com/PenroseTiles.html
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penrose_tiling
Print a handful and play with them on your desk or lab bench.

title: CTC, FF, Replicator Filament Spool holder, roller upgrade

description.text:
There are many spool holders, but nothing that fitted easily on the back, using the hole that was for the original spool holder. You will need 6mm plywood or Acrylic / perspex etc something to cut it with (Jigsaw, router etc)- use the pdf template as a guide.
Screws, nuts etc.
4 of 25mm countersunk, 8 of 25mm socket head, 2-6 of 16mm M3 screws & 8 nylock nuts, 10 normal nuts, 18 washers all metric 3mm (M3)
2 of 116mm x 6mm stainless / carbon-fiber rod, 2 of 103mm plastic tube (16mm electrical conduit 12mm ID), 4 - 6x 12x 4mm bearings (Flanged if you can get them) note the plastic tube will be shorter if you have the flanged bearings.
After printing the parts, clean the holes with a 3.3mm drill.
Countersink the back of the plywood, use the printer nut and bolt to attach the spool holder to your printer.
Note the nut slots on the cross arms are tight, if they are too tight use a 2.5mm drill to clean the sides of the slots.
The hole in the back plate is slightly offset so flip it for the other side spool holder.
Parts list is for 1 spool holder.
Note Nut is from original CTC spool holder and the Bolt is a remix of the original spool holder.

CTC dual

Notes: The Nut and Bolt - printed at .2 & 15% infill, 2 shells, 1mm top/bottom.
The Spool holder - printed .28 & 10% infill, 2 shells, 1mm top/bottom.
I used rafts because I printed in ABS.

author: DX4217

description.text:
I think it will be better with pilot holes for drilling and an outline for cutting out. I also added lines for heat controlling 0805 thermistor. X,Y are the dimensions of heated area
Steps = number of wires, even integer is recomended
pilot_hole_r is the radius of the pilot holes, helps you to drill (0.2-0.5 mm is OK)
area_r is the safety copper area around holes. Full dimensions will be [x+4area_r,y+4area_r], hole-to hole dinensions will be [x+2area_r,y+2area_r]
Volt is the voltage
Power = power in Watts
Cutout is the thickness of cutout line
Copper_h is the thickness of copper on your board (0.018 and 0.035 are typical)

Order a 3D Print This model of Asteros Hydrogen 3D printed generator is built from 3 printed components designed in Tinkercad and printed on very well calibrated 3D printer, Steel 316L plates cut on laser cutter designed on AutoCAD 2007 to match the 3D printed cell separator. With this project, several groups of students can work as a team to achieve Architect and mechanical design improvements. Print this model to enjoy instant car fuel saving, or get inspired to create and print your own HHO Generator! With this I hope you can understand how big is the universe of 3D printing. More upcoming projects soon. Plates DXF file. Assembling documents and parts list + printing video tutorial.

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes: It is recommended to use Brim of at least 4.8 mm when printing ABS.
Scale it to fit your building volume or print separate the upper barb out and glue it with acetone.
Carefully check the proper connecting of the separator, due it is important, if not glued will separate and when powered will short and thus lead to overheat and destroy the generator and may occur risk of explosion.

Why 3D printed I designed this hydrogen generator to try saving from my fuel bills. The simple reasons I choose 3D printer is that only 3D printer can make the separator and the rest of the parts for a few hours , even some parts can only be 3D printed.
Anybody with 3D Printer can print one for himself
I use to work the very early bird of this HHO generator on CNC machine but to achieve good result I should get very expensive jewelry CNC machine and thus make me think for other less expensive way. I stuck with the best choice with very bright future as 3D printing.

description.header: Project: Asteros B708a 3d printed Hydrogen Generator
description.text:
Objectives: This project covers a wide range of students who can learn on how far reached science and how this Hydrogen generator using every submitted ampere current to produce hydrogen, and not least how it is produced with the help of a relatively new but very fast growing area as 3D printing. The students can try also to design even more further the generator and make it separating HH from the O and make it separator, or changing the shape in better look and designer way. Audiences: Ages from 18+ would be appropriate for this Project since HHO is highly explosive and special care is need for handling and manipulating. Preparation: Computer with internet access and 3D modeling software.
Thing the students need is 3D printer, then the SSteel plates can be ordered for cutting with the DXF files provided on laser cutter from relevant company. Step 1:
Make any changes to the model with Tinkercad or similar 3D editing software, respectively and the DXF files for the Plates with AutoCAD. Step 2:
Print all parts of the generator on 3D printer in color of your choice. Step 3:
Order the SSteel plates and start assembling the generator as shown on the pictures, any changes to the design have to get in count. Result: The most innovative and engineering minded student should get achieved to bring the HHO generator at least to better appearance with minor to major improvements, or even better to bring the generator to next level and make it separator.

comments.text: Did you have to acetone bath this to make it gas tight?
comments.author: mykiscool

comments.text:
Is not anything special, just cut water container and fill it with acetone. Then deep the cell for just seccond, drain all acetone from the piece.Leave for few minutes before touch and don't press with fingers on the soft surface.
If your printer leave empty space between the infill (need to adjust the filament diameter or extrusion multiplier in settings ), the acetone will go insaide and ruine your piece, I sugest to make acetone vapor in this case and then coating with pipe clear glue for sure.
comments.author: mykiscool

comments.text:
With some chinese filament - Yes, you need to do acetone bath to make it water tight.
Usually help, but if not - additional treatment need with pipe glue on the outer side, 2-3 coating, and one after it is assembled especially on the connection lid-shell

title: Penny-Arcade's Pushfight™
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A 3D-printable version of Pushfight that I whipped up after watching a few playthrough videos on Penny-Arcade.com. It looks interesting, and since there isn't an app available to play it out, I thought I'd create a quick version here. Pushfight is now a collaboration between Bretto Inc and Penny-Arcade. You can purchase an actual, real-life Pushfight set here:
http://store.penny-arcade.com/products/push-fight and you can look at Bretto Inc's website here:
http://pushfightgame.com/ E: I've added a V2 for the pieces to help them slide past each other during play. I've also added a version of the board without the pattern on the back, labeled Pushfight_Board_Flat.stl, in case you want to print the board standing up.

The board prints in two pieces, and is glued together in the middle.  Print three block pieces for each team (six total), two round pieces for each team (four total) and one anchor in a unique color not shared by either team.
Here's a quick video demonstrating how to play Pushfight: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hCvms0ATlqE

comments.text: I was just catching up on PA, found out they made a game, and immedtiately thought "$50? Screw that, I'll print it out if I wanted to. I wonder if anyone else..." And here it is.

title: Sitting Spool mount w/Bearings and custom width

description.header:
CHECK OUT MY NEW AND IMPROVED DESIGN, THAT IS EASIER TO ADJUST IN WIDTH USING A SCREW
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2179768

description.text:
This is a filament spool mount holder. It works with 4 bearings. Inner bearings diameter should be 8 mm. The knob is made 8.05 mm, so its a press fitting. I had to sand it down a little myself for a good fit.
It has a custom width, so it should fit most spools. It is quite sturdy, and has a good slide, with the right amount of friction. I recommend fixing an elastic to push the two holders together. UPDATE: I've made a loop around for fixing the elastic, since the stick is not very good (Too tiny). I have not yet printed this, so ill leave both files up. UPDATE2: I've added a new rail with Ø10mm holes for fixing neodymium magnets into. I've used 2 screws into the box where my 3D-print is. This allows for a much better fixture and easy removal when changing filament or when the spool gets in the way.

Watch him move here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6CFrwe9zlvc This adorable little creature's moveable LED-illuminated eyes, functioning jaw, and sleek looking treads make him the most expressive mascot possible. He can be happy, adventurous and fast, big or small. His tail is made up of a ball point pen insert or 3mm section of filament. His eyes light up with 3mm LEDs and a standard cr2032 coin battery with no soldering! Print the eye inserts in glow in the dark and he'll have night vision, perfect for those late night hack-a-thons. He holds a stealthy slot in his back for propping up your notepaper and has acquired a taste for stray paperclips. All around, he's fully printable with no overhangs over 50 degrees and uses the legendary TBUSER (Mad props to him: http://thingiverse.com/tbuser) compatible male/female connectors for open bot-modding goodness. Another video of the little creature from an exploded view here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RlmsoBxgHIM

• Print
    • 1 torso
    • 1 mandible
    • 4 treads
    • 4 tread bases
    • 2 long male/male connectors
    • 2 short male/male connectors
    • 1 tail base
    • 1 tail top
    • 2 eye M inserts
    • 2 eye inserts (best printed in glow-in-the-dark or clear)
    • 2 eye bases
  • Snap together
  • Open the little dude(ette)'s mouth and slide in 2x 3mm LEDS and CR2032 battery
  • Play!

This is an adequately close model of Magneto/Shaw's helmet from x-men first class. Total print time is about 25hrs.
Designed for a 7.5" head width. In hindsight it is a bit too big, and I would scale it by 7/7.5 if I were doing it again.
The first one was printed on a Fablicator.
www.fablicator.com

Use something to cut up the Solidworks or .stl file into printable pieces for your printer.
There are just too many different ways to cut it up for different printers so I left it whole. It is just better if you do it yourself to optimize your ease of printing.
You pretty much have to use PLA. The pieces are to large and thin to use ABS without the 70C heated chamber that almost nobody has yet.
Once printed, I used a soldering iron to CAREFULLY melt the pieces together.
I used a liberal amount of bondo, elbow grease, and sandpaper to make the helmet smooth. The paint used similar to duplicolor metalcast over a black base coat. Bondo, primer, and wet-sanding are your friends; Patience is a virtue.

My goal was to create a cellphone holder utilizing the in-dash CD player (since it is rarely used, yet is still common in many auto makes and models today).  Although a CD is 120 mm in diameter, I had to scale it due to the limitations of my printer.  You may need to enlarge the cable hole on the bottom based upon your phone (or sand it down).  As you can see from the photos it holds the phone well and the charging cable keeps it in place.
Enjoy!

title: Dial Indicator Holder for Cartesio V0.8

description.text:
This is a Dial Indicator holder for Cartesio V0.8 (Extruder v3).  
It will fit Mitutoyo 2046S, 2046SH, 2046S-09, 2046S-15, 2310S-10, 2902S, 2047S metric dial indicators with lug back. FreeCAD file is also available in case you want to change the dimensions for other dial indicators.  
With the build platform at highest position (Z=0) the dial indicator should be around 5mm (middle of its measurement range) so it can be used to measure deviations on both up and down direction.

description.text: The outer surface is thicker than the first version of the probe bracket, while the inner surface is thinner allowing the probe to slide freely for adjustment. The point where the screw and bracket meet was a common failure point in my prints so I thickened the bracket around the screw. It is recommend you print this piece with 100% infill.

description.text: In time for the holiday season, I have designed a polygonal Christmas tree ornament fit for-well, a Christmas tree, haha. If printed at a 10% infill and a .30 mm print height, everything can be printed within 3 hours and 18 minutes, or shorter depending on your printer. This will require manual assembly, and so I would recommend painting everything before gluing everything together. For the star, I used basic metal wire and glued it into a hole drilled through the top part of the tree. But,hey,it's your tree, who am I to tell you how it will look or be assembled. Regardless, enjoy.
